title: Vintage Label Font
content:
Need help identifying the uppercase letters

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [downsouth2.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140319232219/http:/typophile.com/files/downsouth2.jpg) | 61.87 KB |
author: darby2105

comments.content:
Lettering. The only font I know of that comes anywhere close to the big drop swoosh S is Vulpa, which has it as an alternate italic S. It also has an italic swash D as an alternate. Here they are together with the regular lower case

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140319232219im_/http:/typophile.com/files/VulpaItalicSwashRegLCreducedscale_4435.jpg)
  
The lower case is shown at 80% to approximate the label. You could get the effect by using a smaller point size for the lower case than for the capitals. [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/schizotype/vulpa/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140319232219/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/schizotype/vulpa/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/schizotype/vulpa/")  
Don

Agree with Don. Lettering. Other option, Mark Simonson's Bookman revival [Bookmania](http://web.archive.org/web/20140319232219/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/bookmania) using some stylistic alternates: / [D](http://web.archive.org/web/20140319232219/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/bookmania/italic/glyphs.html#glyphs/519890/611) and / [S](http://web.archive.org/web/20140319232219/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/bookmania/italic/glyphs.html#glyphs/519890/1076)
